Title: Egalitarian but not Equal: Sectoral Wage Formation and Gendered Wage Differentials (WAGE Project)

The WAGE project aims to theorize the gendered nature of collective bargaining, a crucial yet understudied aspect of the persistent gender pay gap (GPG). Globally, women earn 20% less than men, with the European average standing at 13% (United Nations, 2022; Eurostat, 2022). This project focuses on Germany, Norway, and Sweden, examining the metal sector and nursing sector to uncover the daily practices and social norms that contribute to sectoral gendered wage differentials.

Through ethnographic research, the WAGE project will achieve three primary objectives. First, it will synthesize existing histories of collective bargaining and the GPG in the three selected countries. Second, it will analyze daily practices in collective bargaining rounds that result in wage increases in the male-dominated metal sector and the female-dominated nursing sector. Third, it will document and explain how actors in these sectors relate to the wage norm and sectoral gendered wage differentials.

By exploring the intricacies of collective bargaining and its gendered implications, the WAGE project will provide novel insights into the persistence of the GPG. Our findings will inform policy and practice, ultimately contributing to more equitable wage formation and a reduction in the GPG. The project's interdisciplinary approach, combining sociology, economics, and gender studies, will foster a more nuanced understanding of the complex dynamics underlying the GPG, paving the way for a more egalitarian society.

The research objectives include comparing collective bargaining histories, analyzing wage increase negotiations, and documenting how actors in each sector relate to wage norms and gendered wage differentials. Title: Egalitarian but not Equal: Sectoral Wage Formation and Gendered Wage Differentials (WAGE Project)

The WAGE project aims to theorize the gendered nature of collective bargaining, focusing on the persistence of gendered wage differentials in three European countries: Germany, Norway, and Sweden. Despite egalitarian principles, women face a significant pay gap, averaging 20% globally and 13% in Europe, according to the United Nations (2022) and Eurostat (2022). This project seeks to uncover the underlying mechanisms perpetuating this disparity.

Through ethnographic research, the WAGE project will investigate collective bargaining practices in the male-dominated metal sector and the female-dominated nursing sector. The research objectives are threefold: (1) to synthesize existing histories of collective bargaining and the gender pay gap in the three selected countries, (2) to analyze daily practices in collective bargaining rounds that result in wage increases in the two sectors, and (3) to document how actors in these sectors relate to the wage norm and sectoral gendered wage differentials.

By exploring the social and cultural dynamics of collective bargaining, the WAGE project will provide new insights into the gendered nature of wage formation and contribute to a deeper understanding of the persistence of gendered wage differentials. The project's findings will inform policy and practice, ultimately helping to reduce the gender pay gap and promote greater economic equality.
